The Earth is getting warmer due to human activity. This is causing changes to the weather and the planet's climate. The changes are affecting plants, animals, water and soils. They are also having a significant impact on human societies.
The main cause of climate change is the increase in greenhouse gases in the atmosphere. These gases trap heat from the sun and cause the Earth's atmosphere to warm up. The amount of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere has increased significantly over the last 100 years. This is due to human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation.
Climate change is causing a number of changes to the planet's climate. These changes include changes in precipitation patterns, changes in the timing of seasons, and changes in the distribution of ecosystems. These changes are having a negative impact on many human societies.
The most severe consequences of climate change are rising sea levels and increased flooding. Rising sea levels are caused by the thermal expansion of the ocean and the melting of glaciers. Increased flooding is a major problem for coastal communities around the world. It can damage infrastructure, destroy homes and livelihoods, and displace people.

Aesthetics is a field that studies the nature of beauty and art. However, the existence of artworks often creates obstacles to understanding aesthetic theory. One reason is that artworks are physical products that exist outside of human experience. This makes it difficult to understand how artworks relate to human experiences. Additionally, the perfection of some artworks and their long history of admiration create conventions that get in the way of fresh insight. When artworks are isolated from their original conditions and experiences, they become difficult to understand. To understand artworks, we need to forget them for a time and turn aside from them. Instead, we need to focus on the ordinary forces and conditions of experience that we do not usually regard as aesthetic. This means that we need to arrive at the theory of art by means of a detour. Once we have done this, we can appreciate artworks in their raw form and enjoy them as part of our daily experiences.

There are some activities that take a long time to complete. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you are impatient and add the oil too quickly, the mayonnaise curdles. If you start tugging with frustration on a tangled fishing line, the knot just becomes tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some of its functions are performed at lightning speeds; others take seconds, minutes, hours, days or even years to complete their course. Some can be speeded up - we can become quicker at solving crossword puzzles or doing mental arithmetic. But others cannot be rushed, and if they are, then they will break down, like the mayonnaise, or get tangled up, like the fishing line.
The mind possesses three different processing speeds. The first is faster than thought. The second is thought itself. The third is slower than thought. This slower mode of thinking is often less purposeful and clear-cut, more playful, leisurely or dreamy. It is often less purposeful and clear-cut, more playful, leisurely or dreamy. Allowing the mind time to meander is not a luxury that can safely be cut back as life or work gets more demanding. On the contrary, thinking slowly is a vital part al the cognitive armoury.

I have been welcomed warmly to a sociable and well-provisioned base camp in a very isolated place. There are a lot of people living there, but I don't have much trouble communicating. The film director Alfred Hitchcock always insisted that he didn't care about the subject matter of his films, or indeed about the acting. He cared about the photography and the soundtrack and all the technical ingredients. Therefore, if a picture is designed correctly, the audience should scream at the same moment. Hitchcock's self-appraisal was always precise, rational, deceptively unanswerable. He was a man of reason and a craftsman of genius who liked to hear an audience scream. He didn't deal in speculation, abstraction or intellectual allusion, and his assessment of his own screen characters was not exploratory. He set his sights on film, pure film, and the most dispassionate, mathematically calculable beauty of what a strip of film can be made to do to an audience.

Amateur Astronomy
Many things have changed in astronomy over the past fifty years. There were not many charts and catalogues, and telescopic equipment was limited. Today, there are many more charts and telescopes available. Computers have made it easier to produce charts and analyze observations. All this makes it a good time for amateur astronomy.
However, there has also been a loss of simplicity. Now you have to travel farther to find a sky that is comparable to the sky in urban areas fifty years ago. The daytime skies are now filled with aircraft condensation trails which can last for hours and often spread out to form amorphous clouds, making solar observations impossible and hampering night-time observation too.
Society is also becoming more complex. There are too many things to do, too many options, and too many opportunities. This can be stressful and tiring. As a result, there is a new trend emerging: the search for 'simplexity' - the simple things that give meaning in an increasingly complex world.
McAndrews Hotel
Every summer we spend a fortnight in McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. It is a family tradition that has been going on for many years. Nothing is allowed to interfere with the ritual. We are of a kind, McAndrews clientele: old-fashioned, odd perhaps, some would say snobbish. I do not like the bad manners, the insolence of shop assistants which passes for egalitarianism in this present age; I resent chummy overtures from waiters who sometimes appear to restrain themselves with difficulty from slapping one on the back. I know most of my fellow-guests' names - like me they have been coming here since they were children - yet can rest assured that when I meet any of them in any part of the hotel, I shall be spared all social intercourse apart from a civil word of greeting. Such respect for dignity and personal privacy is hard to come by in commercial establishments these days.

Writing and reading are two enjoyable activities that require effort. Handwritten text is often more enjoyable to read than text written on a screen. This is because the slowness of handwriting forces the brain to focus and concentrate. It also encourages people to write more carefully. However, the convenience of computers has led to a decline in handwriting. Most writers using word processors find that the time spent correcting early drafts is more or less equates with the time originally spent on handwritten text. Similarly, the e-mail, unlike the handwritten letter, is emotionally ponderous. It is said to have revived the art of the love letter. But printed words written in haste lack the care and character of handwriting.
Books versus Electronic Text
Reading books is a more enjoyable experience than reading text on a screen. Books encourage people to read more slowly and carefully. They also allow people to think about the text in a more joined-up way. Computers do not invite the same joined-up thinking. They encourage people to dip into text rather than read it in its entirety.

Maps are used to show the relationships of points and features on the Earth's surface. They are determined by distance and direction. In the past, distance was often measured in units of time, but such measurements gave more information about the relative ease of crossing the local terrains than about actual distance. Direction is also an important element of maps. The accurate representation of direction was not of primary importance for ordinary travellers. Written itineraries for a long time rivalled maps. Today, certain types of maps, such as those showing railway systems, may make little attempt to show true directions. Landmarks along a route were at first indicated by signs. The history of cartography is largely that of the increase in the accuracy with which distance and direction are determined and the comprehensiveness of the map content. The development of cartography has called in other sciences to its aid. Today, cartography is used in many sciences, including geology, history, and geography.

In the forests of Madagascar, there lives a primate called the aye-aye. The aye-aye is like a woodpecker. It bores through wood and probes cavities beneath the surface to find insect larvae. The aye-aye uses its incisor teeth to gnaw its way in and its narrow, elongated third finger to probe and scoop. Scientists have discovered that the aye-aye can find insects by tapping the surface of the wood and listening for reverberations. The aye-aye can also sense the cavity itself. When searching for food, an aye-aye taps the surface of the wood with its middle finger and brings its exceptionally large ears forward, focusing them at a point in front of its nose.

Cambridge Darkroom is a centre for photography. They offer courses and workshops for people of all ages and abilities. They also have a membership scheme and encourage young photographers to develop their skills.

Science flying in the face of gravity. Journalist Tom Mumford joined students using weightlessness to test their theories. It looked like just another aircraft from the outside. In the 17th century, Sir Edmund Halley was a renowned astronomer who made significant contributions to the field of navigation. He is best known for his discovery of the comet that bears his name. One of his greatest accomplishments was charting the variations of the compass. These variations, known as declination, are the angle between magnetic north and true geographical north. Without declination, sailors were unable to correct their compasses and navigate the oceans accurately.
Halley's journey to chart declination took him to various places, including Cape Verde Islands, Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, and Newfoundland. From these travels, he published a chart that showed the variations of the compass in the Western and Southern Oceans. His work was instrumental for seamen for more than a century.
Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, is planning to commemorate Halley's accomplishments by retracing his route. He has already spent two years in Antarctica and has a deep understanding of geomagnetism. Clark's expedition will involve making precise measurements of declination using advanced instruments. The data collected will help refine existing mathematical models of Earth's magnetic field.

Peacocks that live in Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire, UK, show off their magnificent trains to the hens. They re-enact the mystery that tormented Charles Darwin to his dying day. Darwin argued that living creatures came to be the way they are by evolution, rather than by special creation. He believed that the fittest individuals are most likely to survive and reproduce. However, the peacocks tail was not necessarily advantageous. Darwin felt that the tail was a waste of space and a severe encumbrance.
The zoologist Marion Petrie and her colleagues are now trying to settle the matter. They have identified two main questions. First, do peahens really choose the males with the showiest trains? And, secondly, do the peacocks with the showiest trains have some extra, genuinely advantageous quality, as Wallace supposed, or is it really all show, as Darwin felt?
The study of peacocks at Whipsnade is providing valuable insights into the mechanisms of evolution. It is also helping to clarify Darwin's theories.

In the past few million years, humans and chimpanzees have not significantly changed genetically. We are still more than 98% identical to chimps. Our physical capacity for making art and anything else we consider uniquely human must be due to a small number of genes. Modern studies of animal behaviour have shown that many similarities between humans and animals exist. For example, tools are used by humans and chimpanzees, and sea otters crack open clams with rocks. As for language, monkeys have a simple one, with separate warning sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle' and 'snake'. These discoveries leave us with few absolute differences, other than art, between ourselves and animals.
If human art sprang from a unique genetic endowment, it's strange that our ancestors dispensed with it for at least the first 6.9 million of the 7 million years since they diverged from chimps. The earliest art forms may well have been wood carvings or body painting. But if they were, we wouldn't know it, because those materials don't get preserved. Not until the Cro-Magnons, beginning around 35,000 years ago, do we have unequivocal evidence for a distinctly human art.
There are three main distinctions between human art and animal activities. First, human art is non-utilitarian, it's made for aesthetic pleasure and not for survival or reproduction. Second, human art is learned rather than instinctive. Third, human art is transmitted by learning rather than by genes.
These paintings by our closest relatives, then, do start to blur some distinctions between human art and animal activities. Like human paintings, the ape paintings served no narrow utilitarian functions; they were produced not for material regard but only for the painter's satisfaction.

People spend a third of their lives asleep. Sleep has a vital function, but what that function might be is still in debate. There are three main theories about sleep. The most popular theory says that sleep is mainly for the health of our body. It claims that we sleep in order to maintain the health of our body. The second theory emphasizes the learning benefits of sleep. It holds that sleep allows us to process the information that we acquire during the day. The third theory is based on ideas about energy. It says that we need periods of sleep in order to recharge our batteries and have an adequate supply of energy for the coming day.

The camera can lie. Arthur Conan Doyle, creator of the Sherlock Holmes stories, believed himself to be a rational man, a scientist even. But in 1920, he saw photographs of fairies taken in a garden setting and thought that these tiny creatures really existed.
